author: txholdem
body:
i put $10k in a fidelity IRA, traded options for 3 months, one day i was unable to place an order, fidelity told me they wouln't let me trade options anymore because i turned 10k into 1.7k.

i then bot mu stocks and when i checked 2 years later, the fucking balance didnt not change at all.

2 months ago, i decided to do something. i sold MU, bought SLV. 1 week later, i sold for a 20% loss. i sold and bot OPK. i sold for 40% loss. i bot SPXS, sold for 15% loss. then i bot MFA, 2 days later, i sold for 25% loss.

now i have $475 left.

but who gives a fuck. i put $100 in RH last May, and i will have $4M in a few months.

As for bribery allegations: contra revenue Atoms were 5 years ago, demonstrating that the dirty culture in Intel is alive and well. MDF is also alive and kicking.

author: CrimsonBrit
body:
I appreciate the thought and effort that went into this write-up, however, you've done quite a bit of due diligence to ultimately pick 80% of the **FAANG** stocks (Facebook ($FB), Amazon ($AMZN), Apple ($AAPL), Netflix ($NFLX); and Alphabet ($GOOG) with Netflix being the one you did not pick in your list of six companies.

Each of the FAANG stocks trades on the Nasdaq exchange and is included in the S&P 500 Index. Since the S&P 500 is a broad representation of the market, where the FAANGs make up about 15% of the S&P 500—a staggering figure considering the S&P 500 is generally viewed as a proxy for the United States economy as a whole,  you have basically just invested in the market as a whole, as stated by /u/Chuckox50.

Not to mention that investing in Berkshire ($BRK.A) is like investing in an index fund of sorts, where Berkshire's "fund" also owns positions in Apple (33.9%), Amazon (0.57%), and Johnson & Johnson (0.24%), adding to your positions in those three companies. Additionally, Berkshire owns relatively small positions in the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust ([$SPY](https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/SPY:US)) and VANGUARD IX FUN/S&P 500 ETF SHS NEW ([$VOO](https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/VOO:US)) ETFs, which both track the S&P 500 and in turn have positions in some of the companies you have mentioned: Microsoft ($MSFT), Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Berkshire, Johnson & Johnson, and Alphabet.

**That being said, I still think that they are rock-solid choices and I have several of those on my radar and just as many already in my portfolio, and I intend to add to my positions for those companies.**

I am investing for the long-term and currently have a high tolerance for risk, so the majority of the stocks on my lengthy list of about 55 companies on my radar right now are tech.

Just to mention a bunch of them (on top of MSFT, AAPL, GOOG, NFLX, FB, and AMZN):

* Financial: Visa, Mastercard, PayPal, Square
* Healthcare: JNJ, UnitedHealth, AbbVie, Illumina, InVitae
* Services: AMZN, Walmart, Disney, Spotfiy
* Technology (Software): Oracle, Adobe, Salesforce, Shopify, Splunk, Docusign, Twiliio, The Trade Desk
* Technology (Gaming): Activision Blizzard, Take-Two
* Technology (Semiconductors): Intel, NVIDIA, AMD, Micron, Teradyne
* Telecom/Communications: Verizon, AT&T, Cisco

I would like to caution you for your analysis in the write-up in regards to Berkshire. You state that your rationale for Berkshire having a competitive edge post-COVID-19 is simply "Warren Buffett". By the time that COVID is on the decline, Buffett will be 90 years old. I think the company can thrive without him, but if your basis for investing in that company for the long-term is a man born in 1930, I think you need to reassess your rationale.

author: TheStoicInvestor
body: The loss is actually $500, but in general I agree. I made more than $1000 last year just from my MU covered calls. The issue with covered calls is that they require the capital to buy and hold the stock. So, you need to find stocks that you both like, and have a good IV so you can get a decent premium when you sell the calls.

author: ivalm
body:
Current option positions:

1. 10x $200 QQQ 15Jan2021 Call
2. 10x $180 QQQ 15May2020 Put

For a long time I have been long tech equity (AMD/TEAM/MU/SQ, yes I am meme friendly; i am still holding that equity, didn't sell anything) so I ended up buying QQQ puts to hedge. Originally I held 10x 200/180 QQQ June Put spread (bought this January). Mid February  I bought out the 180 short leg and as QQQ crashed I rerolled the long leg to earlier date/lower strike at every ~100% gain keeping cash (took out about $30k cash out of originally $3.8k spread). The lowest/nearest puts I had were $170 QQQ Apr, but in the past 2 weeks rolled it back up to $180 QQQ May. I probably will not roll in up/forward any more and just let it expire in May worthless if the uptrend continues.

I bought the $200 QQQ Jan2021 Call this Friday.

January is basically 6month after when I am fairly sure US confirmed will start decreasing (hopefully earlier!). When I bought it $QQQ was ~$181 so I chose $200 as ~10% out. I do think that with all the support the financial markets are receiving this will not be a prolonged recession so hopefully we will return to previous $230 level, in which case I don't care what the $VIX will be.  

Although realistically I am already thinking of rolling my calls to higher strikes, taking out cash as we go (went from 12k->18k since Friday). On the down slide this lead to me extracting more cash from the puts than my original $200 QQQ June put is worth now.

author: biochemguy
body:
I am long NVDA.  I have been following the role of machine learning and deep learning in productivity improvements and automation.  NVDA has the gold standard chipset for this use, and is greatly benefiting from this revolution.    


Generally I never invest in manufacturing, and stay away from chip makers.  But this trend is too strong.  So I'm long NVDA, and your only hope is an overall market drop.  If the market trades sideways or up, you are going to be a retard with less money.

author: Fortune_Fus1on
body:
Low end and mid end graphics cards will become obsolete in the coming years because APU's will be good enough to replace them. So nVidia will likely be pushed out of the market there because APUs are a product they can't compete with. 

Right now nVidia only has one main competitor which is AMD, who are too busy drooling on the floor to actually bring them pain, but both Intel and ARM are also entering the market.

On the long term AI algorithms will completely replace traditional game engines which will in turn make GPU's as we know it obsolete, my point in the original comment. Now nVidia are very well positioned to take advantage of this but there is no guarantee they will be the only players in this field, in fact I expect the software guys to come and steal their lunch because: 

1) Game publishers are rich as fuck and have all the money necessary to create this AI hardware divisions
2) Epic Games who own Unreal Engine are 49% owned by Tencent and China has been ramping up their own silicon lately, and I can guarantee they will not miss this chance of controlling PC gaming hardware

Basically nVidia's pie will continue to dwindle on the PC gaming and their growth on emergent markets will also be capped pretty soon.

Thanks for coming to my Ted Talk

author: LifeInAction
body:
It depends, I'm thinking about both actually specifically since they're both somewhat high risk, moving in huge waves right now, figured I'd spread out, so if one drops, I can hopefully have the other to fall back on to hopefully have some reasonable amount of gains. 

Back when everyone was dabbling between AMD and Nvidia, the tech chip stocks, I put all into Nvidia and did end up getting gains, but realized I of course would've gotten significantly more in AMD. There was no way to predict it, so the real smart decision learned would've been to just spread out a bit, and split my cash into both, so if one does particular well, I can at least average and balance with the other. Balancing with BA and DAL is now for similar reason, except these are even higher risk, since they'll either plummet or soar to the moon.

author: Figurativelyryan
body:
I don't favour one brand over the other, they both make decent stuff, I just feel that AMD are in a slightly stronger position.

Data centers AMD lag behind, definitely. But the current Nvidia market share isn't likely to grow in the short term - if anything AMD are still slowly chipping away at it.

I wouldn't gamble on stimulus cheques equating directly to huge sales of high-end graphics cards either, not saying it won't happen, but I certainly wouldn't risk my tendies on Nvidia over it.

The current crop of Radeon driver issues were largely ironed out just before the wu-flu went ballistic, but it's a wildcard - I wouldn't know how to factor that into consumer confidence.

author: KushwalkerDankstar
body: They’re a global data center supplier, what makes you think they aren’t raking in the cash from orders worldwide? You KNOW the increase internet traffic will force more focus on high end equipment, and NVIDIA has that market by a chokehold.

author: Winston_The_Pig
body:
So I wanted to start trading this year fresh. Made some really big wins on retarded fd’s on Tesla, bynd, Spce, as well as many retarded day trades. My scheme was to make $1k bets on companies that I thought were getting short squeezed/meme’d. 

The first massive downie was from getting sooo close to $25k that I went full retard in the days of pokimane and had about $15k in Msft and nvidia calls. 

Came back up when I decided to be a gay bear on rcl, dal, Wynn, spy,

Lost about 60% of my account on my first work at home day - drinking and averaging down on the witching hour (started out as a $500 dumb bet that I knew was dumb but I still kept averaging down until I stupidly had $13k into the position). 

On a side note during this time my rollover ira has gone from $6k to $20k - bought the same bear positions but didn’t use any of that money on the witching shit.
